speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) concluded a two-day meeting earlier today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you already know from our statement, the Committee decided today to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to ¼ percent and to make no change in either its asset purchase program or its forward guidance regarding the federal funds rate target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I will discuss the rationales for our decision in a moment.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Economic growth has generally been proceeding at a moderate pace, with continued—albeit somewhat uneven—improvement in labor market conditions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Of course, to say that the job market has improved does not imply that current conditions are satisfactory.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Notably, at 7.3 percent, the unemployment rate remains well above acceptable levels.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Long-term unemployment and underemployment remain high.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we have seen ongoing declines in labor force participation, which likely reflects discouragement on the part of many potential workers as well as longer-term influences, such as the aging of the population.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In the Committee’s assessment, the downside risks to growth have diminished, on net, over the past year, reflecting, among other factors, somewhat better economic and financial conditions in Europe and increased confidence on the part of households and firms in the staying power of the U.S. recovery.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, the tightening of financial conditions observed in recent months, if sustained, could slow the pace of improvement in the economy and the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In addition, federal fiscal policy continues to be an important restraint on growth and a source of downside risk.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Apart from some fluctuations due primarily to changes in oil prices, inflation has continued to run below the Committee’s 2 percent longer-term objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee recognizes that inflation persistently below its objective could pose risks to economic performance, and we will continue to monitor inflation developments closely.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, the unwinding of some transitory factors has led to moderately higher inflation recently, as expected.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, with longer-term inflation expectations well anchored, the Committee anticipates that inflation will gradually move back toward 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In conjunction with this meeting, the 17 participants in our policy discussions—5 Board members and 12 Reserve Bank presidents—submitted individual economic projections.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As always, each participant’s projections are conditioned on his or her own view of appropriate monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Also, at this meeting, we extended the horizon of our projections through 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Generally, the projections of individual participants show that they continue to expect moderate economic growth, picking up over time, as well as gradual progress towards levels of unemployment and inflation, consistent with the Federal Reserve’s statutory mandate to foster maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: More specifically, participants’ projections for economic growth have a central tendency of 2.0 to 2.3 percent for 2013, rising to 2.9 to 3.1 percent in 2014 and 2.5 to 3.3 percent in 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For the unemployment rate, the central tendency of projections for the fourth quarter of each year is 7.1 to 7.3 percent for 2013, declining to 6.4 to 6.8 percent in 2014 and, by 2016, to 5.4 to 5.9 percent—about the longer-run normal level for the unemployment rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Most participants see inflation gradually increasing from its current low level toward the Committee’s longer-run objective of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The central tendency of their projections for inflation is 1.1 to 1.2 percent for this year, 1.3 to 1.8 percent for 2014, and 1.7 to 2.0 percent in 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: With unemployment still elevated and inflation projected to run below the Committee’s longer-run objective, the Committee is continuing its highly accommodative policies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you know, in normal times, the Committee eases monetary policy by lowering its target for the short-term policy interest rate, the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, the target range for the federal funds rate, currently at 0 to ¼ percent, cannot be lowered meaningfully further.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Accordingly, the Committee has been providing policy support to the economy through two complementary methods: by purchasing and holding Treasury securities and agency mortgage-backed securities and by communicating the Committee’s plans for setting the federal funds rate target over the medium term.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I’ll discuss these tools in turn, beginning with our program of asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In September 2012, the FOMC initiated a program of purchasing $40 billion per month in agency mortgage-backed securities, in addition to the $45 billion per month in longer-term Treasury securities that we were already acquiring as part of our maturity extension program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We stated that, subject to our ongoing assessment of the efficacy and costs of the program, purchases would continue until we saw a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market in a context of price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In December 2012, we announced that we would continue to purchase $45 billion per month in longer-term Treasuries after the maturity extension program ended later that month.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thus, our total purchases of longer-term securities were maintained at $85 billion per month, in addition to the reinvestment or rolling over of maturing securities on our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee agreed today to continue asset purchases at that rate, subject to the same conditions that we laid out a year ago.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Because the Committee tied its asset purchases to the outlook for the labor market, it’s important to assess how that outlook has evolved.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As I noted earlier, conditions in the job market today are still far from what all of us would like to see.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Nevertheless, meaningful progress has been made in the year since we announced the asset purchase program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, the unemployment rate has fallen from 8.1 percent at the time of our announcement to 7.3 percent today, and about 2.3 million private-sector jobs have been created over the same period.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Over the past 12 months, aggregate hours of work are up by about 2.4 percent, weekly new claims for unemployment insurance have fallen by about 50,000, and surveys suggest that households perceive jobs as more readily available.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Importantly, these gains were achieved despite substantial fiscal headwinds, which are likely slowing economic growth this year by a percentage point, or more, and reducing employment by hundreds of thousands of jobs.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Not all labor market developments over the past year were positive, however; notably, the labor force participation rate fell by about 0.3 percentage points and real wages remained about flat.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In light of this cumulative progress, the FOMC concluded at our June meeting that the criterion of substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market might well be met over the subsequent year or so.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Accordingly, the Committee sought to provide more guidance on how the pace of purchases might be adjusted over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee anticipated in June that, subject to certain conditions, it might be appropriate to begin to moderate the pace of purchases later this year, continuing to reduce the pace of purchases in measured steps through the first half of next year, and ending purchases around midyear 2014.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, we also made clear at that time that adjustments to the pace of purchases would depend importantly on the evolution of the economic outlook—in particular, on the receipt of evidence supporting the Committee’s expectation that gains in the labor market will be sustained and that inflation is moving back towards its 2 percent objective over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: At the meeting concluded earlier today, the sense of the Committee was that the broad contours of the medium-term economic outlook—including economic growth sufficient to support ongoing gains in the labor market, and inflation moving towards its objective—were close to the views it held in June.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But in evaluating whether a modest reduction in the pace of asset purchases would be appropriate at this meeting, however, the Committee concluded that the economic data do not yet provide sufficient confirmation of its baseline outlook to warrant such a reduction.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Moreover, the Committee has some concern that the rapid tightening of financial conditions in recent months could have the effect of slowing growth, as I noted earlier, a concern that would be exacerbated if conditions tightened further.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Finally, the extent of the effects of restrictive fiscal policies remain unclear, and upcoming fiscal debates may involve additional risks to financial markets and to the broader economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In light of these uncertainties, the Committee decided to await more evidence that the recovery’s progress will be sustained before adjusting the pace of asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee will, of course, continue to monitor economic and financial developments closely.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As noted in today’s statement, in judging when to moderate the pace of asset purchases, the Committee will, at its coming meetings, assess whether incoming information continues to support the Committee’s expectation of ongoing improvement in labor market conditions and inflation moving back towards its longer-run objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, as we have said, and as today’s decision underscores, asset purchases are not on a preset course.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee’s decisions about their pace will remain contingent on the economic outlook and on the Committee’s ongoing assessment of the likely efficacy and costs of the program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me turn now to the FOMC’s forward guidance regarding the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee again reaffirmed its expectation that the current exceptionally low range for the funds rate will be appropriate at least as long as the unemployment rate remains above 6½ percent, so long as inflation and inflation expectations remain well behaved as described in our statement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As I have noted frequently, the economic conditions we have set out as preceding any future rate increase are thresholds, not triggers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, a decline in the unemployment rate to 6½ percent would not lead automatically to an increase in the federal funds rate target, but would, instead, indicate only that it had become appropriate for the Committee to consider whether the broader economic outlook justified such an increase.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee would be unlikely to increase rates if inflation were projected to remain below our 2 percent objective for some time, for example; and, in making its assessment, the Committee would also take into account additional measures of labor market conditions, such as job gains.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thus, the first increases in short-term rates might not occur until the unemployment rate is considerably below 6½ percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The projections of the path of the federal funds rate by individual Committee participants are generally consistent with this guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Although the central tendency of the projected unemployment rate for the fourth quarter of next year encompasses 6½ percent, 12 of the 17 participants expect the first rate increase to take place in 2015 and two expect it to occur in 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Most participants also see the funds rate target rising only very slowly after the process of removing policy accommodation begins.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The median projected funds rate for the end of 2015 is 1 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And notably, although the central tendencies of the projections for both inflation and the unemployment rate in 2016 are close to the longer-run normal values for those variables, the median projection for the federal funds rate at the end of 2016 is 2 percent, well below the longer-run normal value for the federal funds rate of 4 percent or so projected by most participants.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Committee participants generally believe that, because the headwinds to recovery will abate only gradually, achieving and maintaining maximum employment and price stability will require a patient policy approach that involves keeping the target for the federal funds rate below its longer-run normal value for some time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me close by noting that although the FOMC is employing two instruments of policy—asset purchases and forward guidance about short-term interest rates—the overall stance of monetary policy is what matters for growth, jobs, and inflation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our program of asset purchases was set up a year ago to help achieve a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market in the context of price stability, relative to conditions when the program was initiated, and we have made progress toward meeting that criterion.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, even after asset purchases are wound down—which we will do in a manner that is both deliberate and dependent on the incoming economic data—the Federal Reserve’s rates guidance and its ongoing holdings of securities will ensure that monetary policy remains highly accommodative, consistent with an aggressive pursuit of our mandated objectives of maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thank you, and I’d be glad to take your questions.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: Thanks, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: Pedro da Costa from Reuters.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: You cite meaningful progress on the labor market both on the unemployment front and in terms of payroll growth.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: But much of the decline in the unemployment rate has been due, as you know, to the decline in participation.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: So my question to you is—and also on the payroll front, some people would argue that, while there has been growth, it hasn’t been strong enough to keep up with population growth and make up the gap that we have from the recession.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: So, how high do you think the jobless rate would be if it were not for the decline in participation?

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: I’ve heard estimates as high as 10 to 11 percent.

speaker: PEDRO DA COSTA
sentence: And could you put the labor market in that context?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Certainly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, I think there is a cyclical component to participation, and, in that respect, the unemployment rate understates the amount of sort of true unemployment, if you will, in the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But on the other hand, there is also a downward trend in participation in our economy, which is arising from factors that have been going on for some time, including an aging population, lower participation by prime-age males, fewer women in the labor force—other factors which aren’t really related to this recession.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Over the last year, the unemployment rate has dropped by eight-tenths of a percentage point.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The participation rate has dropped by three-tenths of a percentage point, which is pretty close to the trend.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, in other words, I think it would be fair to say that most of the improvement in the unemployment rate—not all, but most of it in the last year—is due to job creation rather than lower participation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would also note that if you look at the broader measures of unemployment that the BLS publishes, including part-time work, including discouraged workers and so on, you’ll see that those rates have fallen about the same amount as the overall standard civilian unemployment rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I think that there has been progress, and it’s obscured to some extent by the downward trend in participation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I also would agree with you that the unemployment rate, while perhaps the best single indicator of the state of labor market, is not by itself a fully representative indicator.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: Binya Appelbaum, the New York Times.

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: To what extent do you regard yourself as responsible for the tightening in financial conditions that you noted?

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: Was it a mistake to talk about tapering in the way that you did in June and do you stand by your guidance that it will be appropriate?

speaker: BINYAMIN APPELBAUM
sentence: Do you still expect that it will be appropriate to dial down asset purchases by the end of this year?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So to answer the first part of your question, I think there’s no alternative in making monetary policy but to communicate as clearly as possible, and that’s what we tried to do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As of June, we had made meaningful progress in labor market conditions, and the Committee thought that was the time to begin talking about how the eventual wind-down of the program would take place and how it would be tied to the evolution of economic variables.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, in particular, I talked about a proposed strategy that would take about a year for the total wind-down to take place and which, in turn, was also fully contingent on the ratification—so to speak—of our outlook, which included continued improvements in the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So all of that was very consistent with what we said when we began the program, that our goal was to achieve a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market, and we needed to communicate how that was going to be put into practice.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Failing to communicate that information would have risked creating a large divergence between market expectations, public expectations, and what the Committee intentions were, and that could have led to much more serious problems down the road.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I think the communication was very important.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The general framework—to answer the other part of your question, the general framework in which we’re operating is still the same.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We have a three-part baseline projection, which involves increasing growth that’s picking up over time as fiscal drag is reduced, continuing gains in the labor market, and inflation moving back towards objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are looking to see—in the coming meetings, we’ll be looking to see if the data confirm that basic outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If it does, we’ll take a first step at some point—possibly later this year—and then continue so long as the data are consistent with that continued progress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so that basic structure is still in place.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But what I want to emphasize is really two things.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: First, as I’ve said, asset purchases are not on a preset course, they are conditional on the data.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: They’ve always been conditional on the data.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, secondly, that even as we move from asset purchases to rate policy as the principal tool of monetary policy, it’s our intent to maintain a highly accommodative policy and to provide the support necessary for our economy to recover and to provide jobs for our citizens.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: Jon Hilsenrath from the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: Just to follow up on Binya’s question, Mr. Chairman, you said that you could pull back the purchases possibly later this year.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: You sound a little bit less certain that it’s going to happen later this year.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: So I’d like you—to ask you to talk a little bit more about your conviction about whether these are like—the pullback is likely to start this year, where do you stand on that?

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: And I also don’t think I heard you mentioned that 7 percent unemployment number that you’ve talked—you talked about back in June.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: That was the rate that was—the unemployment rate that was supposed to prevail when the Fed was done doing this.

speaker: JON HILSENRATH
sentence: Is that no longer operative?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So there is no fixed calendar—schedule, I really have to emphasize that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If the data confirm our basic outlook, if we gain more confidence in that outlook and we believe that the three-part test that I mentioned is indeed coming to pass, then we could move later this year, we could begin later this year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But even if we do that, the subsequent steps will be dependent on continued progress in the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we are tied to the data—we don’t have a fixed calendar schedule—but we do have the same basic framework that I described in June.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The criterion for ending the asset purchases program is a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Last time, I gave 7 percent as an indicative number to give you some sense of, you know, where that might be.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, as my first answer suggested, the unemployment rate is not necessarily a great measure, in all circumstances, of the state of the labor market overall.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, just last month, the decline in the unemployment rate came about more than entirely because of declining participation, not because of increased jobs.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So what we will be looking at is the overall labor market situation, including the unemployment rate, but including other factors as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, in particular, there is not any magic number that we are shooting for.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re looking for overall improvement in the labor market.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Steve Liesman, with CNBC.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Mr. Chairman, one question—just three parts, if you don’t mind.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Have you indicated to President Obama you did not want to serve a third term?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: If so, when?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Or did President Obama indicate to you he did not want you to serve a third term?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And those two parts notwithstanding, would you serve a third term if asked, either wholly or in part?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, it’s convenient because I have the same answer to all three parts of your question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If you will indulge me just a little longer, I prefer not to talk about my plans at this point.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I hope to have more information for you at some reasonably soon date, but today I want to focus on monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I’d prefer not to talk about my own plans.

speaker: YLAN MUI
sentence: Ylan Mui, Washington Post.

speaker: YLAN MUI
sentence: You mentioned that tighter fiscal conditions are a concern for the Committee as you guys think about whether or not it’s appropriate to reduce asset purchases.

speaker: YLAN MUI
sentence: What do you all expect to be able to do in the future, when you actually do begin to pull back in your asset purchases, to manage expectations and manage the market reactions such that we don’t see another increase in rates?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNAKE
sentence: What’s the relationship between the pullback and fiscal policy?

speaker: YLAN MUI
sentence: Oh, I’m sorry.

speaker: YLAN MUI
sentence: I meant financial conditions, tighter financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Oh, tighter financial conditions, sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I think part of the reaction we’ve seen—and it comes from a number of sources—part of it comes from improved economic news and that’s part of the reason why rates have gone up in other countries as well as in the United States.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that—to the extent that tighter financial conditions reflect a better outlook, that’s a good thing, and that’s not a problem at all.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Part of it reflects views about monetary policy, and that we want to make sure we get straight.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that’s why—to answer the earlier question, again, it’s why communication is so important.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We need to explain, as best we can, how we’re going to move and on what basis we’re going to move.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s much more difficult today than it was 20 years ago because the tools are more complex so they’re less familiar, but that’s still very important.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think the other factor which was at play was an unwinding of excessively risky and levered positions in the markets, and insufficiencies of liquidity in some cases meant that those unwindings led to larger reactions in prices and rates than might otherwise have occurred.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, the tightening associated with that is, to some extent, unwelcome, but, on the other hand, to the extent that some of the riskier, more levered positions have been eliminated, I think that makes the situation more sustainable and reduces, at least, the risk that there will be an over-strong reaction to further announcements.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we will do our best to communicate clearly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That is our goal and our objective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The more clearly we communicate, the better the chance that markets will understand our intentions and that we can avoid any sharp movements.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, again, we’re dealing with tools that are less familiar, harder to quantify, and harder to communicate about than the traditional funds rate.

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: Robin Harding, from the Financial Times.

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: Mr. Chairman, the median Committee member expects a 2 percent interest rate at the end of 2016, and, in the long run, they expect interest rates to return to 4 percent.

speaker: ROBIN HARDING
sentence: Can you give us any sense of when you and when the Committee expect interest rates to get back to that 4 percent figure?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me first restate the—I think the key point here, which is that the large majority of the participants of the FOMC, including voting and nonvoting members who are asked to describe their own assessment of optimal policy—the large majority of them estimate that the appropriate target for the federal funds rate at the end of 2016 will be around 2 percent, even though at that time the economy should be close to full employment, according to our best projections.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The reason for that—there may be possibly several reasons, but we did discuss this in the Committee today—the primary reason for that low value is that we expect that a number of factors—including the slow recovery of the housing sector, continued fiscal drag, perhaps continued effects from the financial crisis—may still prove to be headwinds to the recovery.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And even though we can achieve full employment, doing so will be done by using rates lower than, sort of, the long-run normal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, in other words, in economics terms, the equilibrium rate, the rate that achieves full employment, looks like it will be lower for a time because of these headwinds that will be slowing aggregate demand growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that’s why we expect to see growth that—I mean, rates at an unusually low level.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I imagine it would take a few more years after that to get to the 4 percent level.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I couldn’t be much more precise than that—I mean, we’re already obviously stretching the bounds of credibility to talk about specific projections to 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I think you would expect to see that rates would gradually rise for the two or three years after 2016 and ultimately get to 4 percent.

speaker: JOSH ZUMBRUN
sentence: Mr. Chairman, Josh Zumbrun from Bloomberg News.

speaker: JOSH ZUMBRUN
sentence: You indicated that you can see the Fed lowering the pace of purchases once the economy starts to grow faster, in line with what the Fed’s projected.

speaker: JOSH ZUMBRUN
sentence: For about the past four years, the Fed has been projecting that growth would quicken to about 3 percent, and it never has.

speaker: JOSH ZUMBRUN
sentence: So, at what point are you decide—going to decide that other costs and benefits are the reason that you’re making the decision?

speaker: JOSH ZUMBRUN
sentence: Are we getting close to that having to be a deciding factor even if you don’t get the growth forecast, the way you haven’t the past four years?

speaker: JOSH ZUMBRUN
sentence: And does the complication of this— this is kind of a second question, but I’m going to do it anyway—does the complication of this mean that you need a press conference to make a tapering decision?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, you’re certainly right that we have been over-optimistic about out-year growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are a number of reasons for that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: One reason for it, though, is that it appears—and I talked about this in a speech last year—it appears that, as part of the aftermath of the financial crisis, that, at least temporarily, the potential growth rate of the economy has been slowed, perhaps because new businesses are not being formed at the same rate, innovation may not be translated into new technologies at the same rate, investment is slower, et cetera.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So it appears, again, that the potential rate of growth of the economy has been slowed somewhat, at least temporarily, by the recession and the financial crisis, and you can see that in the slower productivity figures.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, we have—you know, we haven’t anticipated that slowdown in productivity, and that’s one of the main reasons why we haven’t anticipated the relatively slow growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, it’s important to recognize though that what monetary policy affects is not the potential rate of growth, long-run rate of growth, but rather the cyclical part, the deviation of output and employment from its normal level.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And in predicting the amount of slack in the economy, so to speak, we’ve done a little better.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our predictions of unemployment, for example, have been better than our predictions of growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, in particular, one thing that’s been quite striking is that unemployment—we were too pessimistic on unemployment for this year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Unemployment has fallen faster than we anticipated.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, in that respect, we were too pessimistic rather than too optimistic.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, we’ll continue to do the best we can.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re looking, again, to see confirmation of our broader scenario, which basically is that we’ll continue to see progress in the labor market, that growth will be sufficient to support that progress, and that inflation will be moving back towards target, and that’s what will determine our policy decisions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In terms of press conferences, I think it’s important to say that there’s an understanding in the Committee that we’ve had for a while, that there are eight “real” meetings every year—that every meeting is a meeting in which any policy decision can be taken.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, should anything occur at a meeting without a scheduled press conference that requires additional explanation, we certainly could arrange a public, on-the-record conference call or some other way of answering the media’s questions.

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: Greg Ip of the Economist.

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: You said that you—the Committee would be unlikely to raise the federal funds rate if inflation remains below target, but your own projections have inflation—that’s the midpoint of your inflation projections—below your 2 percent target through 2016.

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: So is that inconsistent with the liftoff in the federal funds rate in that period?

speaker: GREG IP
sentence: And, related, is there a case to be made that your thresholds should be supplemented with a lower bound for the inflation rate—i.e., you won’t tighten if inflation is at or below some lower bound?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So on the latter part, you know, of course, you’re seeing interest rate projections and inflation projections separately.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You’re not seeing them combined by individuals.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Each individual is making their own projection.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think you’re right, I mean, that we should be very reluctant to raise rates if inflation remains persistently below target, and that’s one of the reasons that I think we can be very patient in raising the federal funds rate since we have not seen any inflation pressure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On having an inflation floor, that would be in addition to the guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are discussing how we might clarify the guidance on the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That is certainly one possibility.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I guess an interesting question there is whether we need additional guidance on that, given that we do have a target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, of course, implicit in our policy strategy is trying to reach that target for inflation, but that—an inflation floor is certainly something that, you know, could be a sensible modification or addition to the guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: VICTORIA McGRANE.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Victoria McGrane, Dow Jones Newswires.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Many investors were expecting the Fed to move at least a little bit in pulling back the bond-buying program today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Given that you all decided not to do that, are—do you have any concerns that, once again, the Fed is confusing investors and sending mixed signals?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I don’t recall stating that we would do any particular thing in this meeting.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: What we are going to do is the right thing for the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And our assessment of the data since June is that, taken collectively, that it didn’t quite meet the standard of satisfying our—or of ratifying or confirming our basic outlook for, again, increasing growth, improving labor markets, and inflation moving back towards target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We try our best to communicate to markets—we’ll continue to do that—but we can’t let market expectations dictate our policy actions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Our policy actions have to be determined by our best assessment of what’s needed for the economy.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Peter Barnes, Fox Business, sir.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: You mentioned fiscal issues in the statement today.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Are you concerned about a government shutdown?

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: We’re hearing more about that possibility.

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Did that come up in your discussions at this meeting?

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: What do you think would be the impact of a government shutdown on the economy, and what could the Fed’s—or, would the Fed be prepared to respond to that and help the economy with additional accommodation, for example, additional asset purchases?

speaker: PETER BARNES
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, a factor that did concern us in our discussion was some upcoming fiscal policy decisions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would include both the possibility of a government shutdown, but also the debt limit issue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: These are obviously, you know, part of a very complicated set of legislative decisions, strategies, battles, et cetera, which I won’t get into.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But it is the case, I think, that a government shutdown—and perhaps, even more so, a failure to raise the debt limit—could have very serious consequences for the financial markets and for the economy, and the Federal Reserve’s policy is to do whatever we can to keep the economy on course.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, if these actions led the economy to slow, then we would have to take that into account, surely.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So this is one of the risks that we are looking at as we think about policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, you know, again, our ability to offset these shocks is very limited, particularly a debt limit shock.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I think it’s extraordinarily important that Congress and the Administration work together to find a way to make sure that the government is funded, public services are provided, that the government pays its bills, and that we avoid any kind of event like 2011, which had, at least for a time, a noticeable adverse effect on confidence and on the economy.

speaker: ANNALYN KURTZ
sentence: Annalyn Kurtz, with CNNMoney.

speaker: ANNALYN KURTZ
sentence: This week marks five years since the financial crisis began, and Hank Paulson, who you’ve worked very closely with, has said his biggest regret was that he wasn’t able to convince the American people that what was done— the bank bailouts—weren’t for Wall Street, they were for Main Street.

speaker: ANNALYN KURTZ
sentence: What is your biggest regret as you reflect on the five-year anniversary?

speaker: ANNALYN KURTZ
sentence: And do you believe that the Fed, Congress, and the President have put the necessary measures in place to prevent another deep financial crisis?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, on regrets, as Frank Sinatra says, I have many.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think my—you know, reasonably, the biggest regret I have is that we didn’t forestall the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think once the crisis got going, it was extremely hard to prevent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You know, I think we did what we could, given the powers that we had, and I would agree with Hank that we were motivated entirely by the interest of the broader public, that our goal was to stabilize the financial system so that it would not bring the economy down, so that it would not create massive unemployment and economic hardship that was even more—that would have been even more severe by many times than what we actually saw.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I agree with him on that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I guess, since you gave me the opportunity, I would mention that, of course, all the money that was used in those operations has been paid back with interest.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, it hasn’t been costly, even from a fiscal point of view.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, in terms of progress, that’s a good question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think we’ve made a lot of progress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We had, of course, the Dodd–Frank law passed in 2010, and then we recently, you know, have come to agreement internationally on a number of measures, including Basel III and other agreements relating to the shadow banking system and other aspects of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think that our—today, our large financial firms, for example, are better capitalized by far than they were certainly during the crisis and even before the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Supervision is tougher.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do stress testing to make sure that firms can withstand not only normal shocks, but very, very large shocks, similar to those they experienced in 2008.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, very importantly, of course, we now have a tool that we didn’t have in 2008—which would have made, I think, a significant difference if we had had it—which is the orderly liquidation authority that the Dodd–Frank bill gave to the FDIC in collaboration with the Fed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Under the orderly liquidation authority, the FDIC, with other agencies, has the ability to wind down a failing financial firm in a way that minimizes the direct impact on the financial markets and on the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, I should say, I don’t want to overstate the case—I think there’s a lot more work to be done.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In the case of resolution regimes, for example, the United States has set the course internationally.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Other countries and international bodies like the FSB are setting up standards for resolution regimes, which are very similar to those of the United States, which is going to make for better cooperation across borders.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But we’re still some distance from being fully geared up to work with foreign counterparts to successfully wind down an international—multinational financial firm.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that’s—we’ve made progress in that direction, but we need to do more, I think.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, I think there’s more to be done.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There’s more to be done on derivatives, although a lot has been done to make them more transparent and to make the trading of derivatives safer.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But it’s going to be probably some time before, you know, all of this stuff that has been undertaken, all of these measures are fully implemented.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we can assess, you know, the ultimate impact on the financial system.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: Steve Beckner of MNI, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: A number of economists, and, indeed, some of your Fed colleagues, have argued that the effectiveness of quantitative easing has greatly diminished, if not disappeared, and they point to the recent performance of the economy as proof of that.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: And there have been a number of people who have argued that there are regulatory and other impediments to growth beyond the reach of monetary policy.

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: To what extent are these valid arguments?

speaker: STEVE BECKNER
sentence: And if the economy does not speed up, if it does not reach your objectives, how will you ever get out of quantitative easing?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, on the effectiveness of our asset purchases, it’s difficult to get a precise measure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There’s a large academic literature on this subject, and they have a range of results, some suggesting that this is a quite powerful tool, some that it’s less powerful.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: My own assessment is that it has been effective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If you look at the recovery, you see that some of the strongest sectors, the leading sectors like housing and autos, have been interest-sensitive sectors.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that these policies have been successful in strengthening financial conditions, lowering interest rates, and thereby promoting recovery.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I do think that they have been effective.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You mentioned that there hasn’t been any progress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There has been a lot of progress.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As I said at the beginning, labor market indicators, while still not where we’d like them to be, are much better today than they were when we began this latest program a year ago.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, importantly—as actually is referenced in our FOMC statement—that happened notwithstanding a set of fiscal policies which the CBO said would cost between 1 and 1½ percentage points of real growth and hundreds of thousands of jobs.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So the fact that we have maintained improvements in the labor market that are as good or better than the previous year, notwithstanding this fiscal drag, is some indication that there is at least a partial offset from monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, just as you say, there are a lot of things in the economy that monetary policy can’t address.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: They include the effectiveness of regulation, they include fiscal policy, they include developments in the private sector.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do what we can do and what—if we can get help, we’re delighted to have help from other policymakers and from the private sector and we hope that that will happen.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The criterion for ending asset purchases is not, you know, some very high rate of growth.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: What it is is the criterion—let me just remind you, the criterion is a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market, and we have made significant improvement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Ultimately, we will reach that level of substantial improvement, and at that point, we will be able to wind down the asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Again, you know, and I think people don’t fully appreciate that we have two tools: We have asset purchases, and we have rate policy and guidance about rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s our view that the latter, the rate policy, is actually the stronger, more reliable tool.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And when we get to the point where we can, you know, where we are close enough to full employment that rate policy will be sufficient, I think that we will still be able to provide—even if asset purchases are reduced—we will still be able to provide a highly accommodative monetary background that will allow the economy to continue to grow and move towards full employment.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Chairman, Donna Borak, with American Banker.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: The Financial Stability Oversight Council has already designated two nonbank firms as SIFIs, as you know, and potentially a third very soon, and presumably others to follow.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: However, little has been said in terms of how specifically these firms will be regulated by the Fed, which has been a chief criticism of the entire process.

speaker: DONNA BORAK
sentence: Given that, can you provide us any guidance at this point in terms of how far along the Fed is in terms of letting the banks know how they will be regulated besides, you know, tailoring the plans?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, the two firms that have been designated, AIG and GE Capital, actually are—have been regulated by the Fed, because both of them are savings and loan, thrift holding companies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we have a lot of already experience with those firms and a lot of contact with those firms.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We will—I want to use the word “tailored” because we want to design a regime that is appropriate for the business model of the particular firm.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But our other objective, and what makes designation by the FSOC particularly noteworthy, is that the primary goal of the consolidated supervision by the Fed is to make sure that the firms—the firm doesn’t in any way endanger the stability of the broad financial system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we’ll be looking at not just the usual safety and soundness type matters or supervision, which both can be, again, tailored to the types of assets and liabilities that the firm has, but also we’re going to want to focus on things like resolution authority, practices relating to derivatives and other exposures, interconnectedness, et cetera, to make sure that the firm in its structure and in its operations doesn’t pose a threat to the wider system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that’s what is going to be distinctive about our oversight, not only of these designated firms, but also of the large bank holding companies that we already oversee and which we are already subjecting to tougher supervision, higher capital, stress tests, and all the rest.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: Peter Cook of Bloomberg Television, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: One of my colleagues was remarking as we came in here, we don’t often get surprises from the Federal Reserve.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: This was a surprise, you talked about—you hadn’t telegraphed anything specifically, but you’ve seen the market reaction, I’m sure.

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: My question for you is, were you intending a surprise today, and did you get the intended result, judging from the market reaction?

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: And related to that, by taking this action today—continuing the bond purchases going forward—at what point do you believe you’re starting to complicate the exit strategy?

speaker: PETER COOK
sentence: Simply by continuing to keep the Fed’s foot on the gas pedal, do you make life more complicated for the Federal Reserve down the road?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, it’s our intention to try to set policy as appropriate for the economy, as I said earlier.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are somewhat concerned.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I won’t overstate it, but we do want to see the effects of higher interest rates on the economy, particularly in mortgage rates, on housing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So to the extent that our policy makes conditions—our policy decision today makes conditions just a little bit easier, that’s desirable.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We want to make sure that the economy has adequate support and, in particular, it’s less surprising the market or easing policy as it is avoiding a tightening until we can be comfortable that the economy is in fact growing, you know, the way we want it to be growing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So this was a step—it was a step, a precautionary step if you will.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It was a—the intention is to wait a bit longer and to try to get confirming evidence whether to the—to whether or not the economy is, in fact, conforming to this general outlook that we have.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I don’t think that we are complicating anything for future FOMCs.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s true that the assets that we’ve been buying add to the size of our balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But we have developed a variety of tools, and we think we have numerous tools that we—can be used to both manage interest rates and to ultimately unwind the balance sheet when the time comes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I, you know, I’m—I feel quite comfortable that we can—in particular, that we can raise interest rates at the appropriate time, even if the balance sheet remains large for an extended period.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that will be true, of course, for, you know, future FOMCs as well.

speaker: KATE DAVIDSON
sentence: Mr. Chairman, Kate Davidson from Politico.

speaker: KATE DAVIDSON
sentence: Do you think that all of the recent attention being paid to who will be your replacement has had any immediate effect on the Fed, and could it have any lingering effect on your successor?

speaker: KATE DAVIDSON
sentence: And also, do you think the process has just become too politicized, or is this part of a healthy debate?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think the Federal Reserve has strong institutional credibility.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And it is a strong institution, a highly competent institution, and it’s independent, it’s nonpartisan, and I’m not particularly concerned about the political environment for the Federal Reserve.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think the Fed will be—continue to be an important institution in the United States, and that it will maintain its independence going forward.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Greg Robb, MarketWatch.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Was there a discussion among the Committee today about changing the forward guidance, the 6.5 percent jobless rate?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And could you say why the Committee decided to hold that steady in light of the weaker economy?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, as I mentioned earlier, the Committee has regularly reviewed the forward guidance, and there are a number of ways in which the forward guidance could be strengthened.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, Mr. Ip mentioned an inflation floor.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are other steps that we could take.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We could provide more information about what happens after we get to 6.5 percent and those sorts of things, and to the extent that we could provide precise guidance, I think that would be desirable.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, it’s very important that we not take any of these steps lightly, that we make sure we understand all the implications, and that we are comfortable that it will be—that any modifications of the guidance will be credible to markets and to the public.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, we continue to think about options.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are a number of options that we have talked about.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But today, we—as of today, we didn’t choose to make any changes to the guidance.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: Don Lee, L.A. Times.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: As you may know, the Census Bureau reported yesterday that the poverty rate and the median household income saw no improvement last year.

speaker: DON LEE
sentence: And I wonder, when you see median incomes turning up significantly for most people, and in light of the fact that people in the middle and the bottom have seen very little of the gains relative to higher income households, how would you assess the—both quantitative easing and Fed policies?

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that’s certainly the case that there are too many people in poverty.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are a lot of complex issues involved.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are complex measurement issues, I would just have to mention that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There are a lot of issues that are really long-term issues as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: For example, it might seem a puzzle that the U.S. economy gets richer and richer, and yet there are more poor people.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And the explanation, of course, is that our economy is becoming more unequal.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The more very rich people and more people in the lower half who are not doing well, these are—there’s a lot of reasons behind this trend, which has been going on for decades, and economists disagree about the relative importance of things like technology and international trade and unionization and other factors that have contributed to that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I guess my first point is that these long-run trends—it’s important to address these trends, but the Federal Reserve doesn’t really have the tools to address these long-run distributional trends.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: They can only be addressed really by Congress and by the Administration.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And it’s up to them, I think, to take those steps.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Federal Reserve is—we are doing our part to help the median family, the median American, because one of our principal goals—we have two principal goals, one is maximum employment, jobs.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The best way to help families is to create employment opportunities.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re still not satisfied, obviously, with where the labor market, the job market is.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ll continue to try to provide support for that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And then the other goal is price stability, low inflation, which, of course, also helps make the economy work better for people in the middle and the lower parts of the distribution.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we use the tools that we have.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It would be better to have a mix of tools at work—not just monetary policy, but fiscal policy and other policies as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But the Federal Reserve, we can—you know, we only have a certain set of tools, and those are the ones that we use.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Again, our objective—our objectives of creating jobs and maintaining price stability, I think, are quite consistent with helping the average American, but there’s limits to what we can do about long-run trends, and I think those are very important issues that Congress and the Administration, you know, need to look at and decide, you know, what needs to be done there.

speaker: JEREMY TORDJMAN
sentence: Hi, Jeremy Tordjman, with AFP.

speaker: JEREMY TORDJMAN
sentence: Some emerging countries are blaming the Fed policies for the financial distress that they are experiencing.

speaker: JEREMY TORDJMAN
sentence: I wanted to have your take on that.

speaker: JEREMY TORDJMAN
sentence: And also, how did you judge the way the markets reacted to your tapering announcement back in June?

speaker: JEREMY TORDJMAN
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, let me just talk about—I talked a little bit about the communication in June.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me talk just about the emerging markets, which I think is an important issue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me just first say that we have a lot of economists who spend all of their time looking at international aspects of monetary policy, and we spend a lot of time looking at emerging markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I spend a lot of time talking to my colleagues in emerging markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we’re watching that very carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The United States is part of a globally integrated economic and financial system, and problems in emerging markets—or in any country, for that matter—can affect the United States as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, again, we are watching those developments very carefully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It is true that changes in longer-term interest rates in the United States—but also in other advanced economies—does have some effect on emerging markets, particularly those who are trying to peg their exchange rate, and can lead to some capital inflows or outflows.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But there are also other factors that affect inflows and outflows.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Those include changes in risk preference by investors, changes in growth expectations, different perceptions of institutional strength within emerging markets across different countries.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So there are a lot of factors that are there playing a role, and that’s one reason why different emerging markets have had different experiences.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: They have different institutional structures and different policies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, just to come to the bottom line here, we think it’s very important that emerging markets grow and are prosperous.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We pay close attention to what’s happening in those countries—it affects the United States.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The main point, I guess, I would end with, though, is that what we’re trying to do with our monetary policy here is, I think, my colleagues in the emerging markets recognize, is trying to create a stronger U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And a stronger U.S. economy is one of the most important things that could happen to help the economies of emerging markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, again, I think my colleagues in many of the emerging markets appreciate that—notwithstanding some of the effects that they may have felt—that efforts to strengthen the U.S. economy and other advanced economies in Europe and elsewhere ultimately redounds to the benefit of the global economy, including emerging markets as well.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thank you.
